forumNotes.author: wimb
forumNotes.content:
Probably you were to early in removing your USB-stick   
so that binifix4.cmd could NOT do its job to make a correct boot.ini  
You should keep your USB-stick plugged in UNTIL the Windows Desktop Appears and is Ready.  

But now you can edit manually boot.ini yourselves with Notepad (remove first the Read Only Property).  
Make rdisk(0) for the lines to launch WINDOWS and for Default  
and keep rdisk(1) for USB Repair option.  

Try this First and then most likely the lines with partition(4) and C:\\ can be removed.  
I don't know how they came in your boot.ini but it is up to you to decicide about that.

I think I am failing to understand the problem. ![:whistling:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy22.gif)  

If I get it right you cannot boot the Windows already installed on your hard disk if not through the USB stick, right? :wink:  

Which one is the ***Active*** partition on Hard Disk? (Sorry but I cannot get it in Finninsh from the screenshot)  

Does ***that*** partition a bootsector invoking NTLDR?  

Does ***that*** partition contain in it's ROOT NTLDR, NTDETECT.COM and BOOT.INI?  

Make sure of the above.  

Edit the BOOT.INI with multiple entries, like in here:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...ive-t25365.html](http://www.msfn.org/board/BOOTINI-and-different-hard-drive-t25365.html "External link")  

And try each of them...  

Report WHAT happens, exactly, "NTLDR is missing" is one of the strings in bootsector code, the only reasons why it should come out are:  
1) that NTLDR is actually missing on that partition :wink:  
2) that NTLDR is somewhere on the disk "beyond the reach" of bootsector code  
3) that the bootsector DATA or filesystem is invalid  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Compare with the attached.  

Disk 0 has a "Boot" partition (C: ) the ONLY Primary and Active, a Logical Volume spanning the rest of the disk with one "System" partition (G: ) with Win2K - main OS -, a "Swap" partition ( S: ) where the pagefile for ALL systems is, a second "System_2" partition - second Win2K install ( H: ) + several other partitions, one as archive, one as  
Only two of the four available entries in the MBR are used.  
The "Boot" partition also contains DOS and a highly reduced WIN2K system for emergencies.   

I can multiboot anything, without ever needing to change the active partition in the MBR, just through simple BOOT.INI entries.  

Disk 1 is a **worse** example, as all four partition entries in the MBR are taken.  

Anyway the smallish FAT16 partition at the BEGINNING of the volume (the Actiive partition) is the key, as it is compatible with every Operating System, including BeOS (FreeBSD/NetBSD excluded, of course), any kind of DOS, any version of NT based systems, including those with limited addressing capabilities.  

jaclaz

forumNotes.content:
@**Kirka**   

Thanks for your ScreenShots. I think I understand now how it works.  
The Disk Manager shows that your First Partition is an Extended Partition and NOT a Primary Partition.  
The Logical Drive E: of the Extended Partition cannot be Set as Active Partition   
and so is not counted as partition in the arcpath partition numbering for boot.ini.  
The First partition must be a Primary partition which can be Set Active.  

That means that the first Primary partition, which is your partition(2) with Drive G:   
must be numbered as partition(1) in boot.ini  
And that is why we were using first wrong numbers.  

But I must say and agree with **jaclaz** that such partitioning is very unusual and should never be used.  

Is the partitioning Original Or did you Change it before or during XP setup ?  
When was the 2.29 GB partition(1) with drive Letter E: made or is it Original ?
